content: I remember Backdrop community was discussing this somewhere (quick search didn't find), and I'm not sure where that issue was left or decided on. However, just so Backdrop community knows: Password reset form for Drupal no longer reveals if the username or email address is a valid account https://www.drupal.org/node/3189618

@Alan Mels Yes! My issue: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4696

Change message for incorrect login/password reset for (slightly) better security/privacy · Issue #4696 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
If I enter my username in the Reset Password form (/user/password) and submit, I see this message: Further instructions have been sent to your e-mail address. If I enter a made-up username in the s...
Thanks for pointing the issue, @BWPanda I've just posted the link to Drupal issue there. I personally would support following Drupal's suit not to reveal if an account is registered or not.

@Alan Mels we investigated that issue way back when, and instead decided to follow the prevailing recommendations that the user-experience of knowing if you are entering the correct email address (or username) vastly outweighed any security benefit you'd get by confusing everyone.
Maybe this can be a configurable setting, so people like @Alan Mels and myself who prefer privacy for their site can have that, while those who need better UX can have that instead...?

Hi @jenlampton . Thanks for the update. I've just left my opinion on this on https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4696

I just read through all the comments on the drupal issue. It looks like most of the concerns there were ignored. I've left a reeeeealy long comment on our issue trying to sumarize.

It looks like most of the concerns there were ignored.

:oh_no:
thats how drupal works, if there are enough people willing to move something forward, it can get in. That's why we're here :)

I also created https://github.com/backdrop-ops/contrib/issues/490 :)

I'm glad Backdrop is willing to put stuff into core that otherwise would be a "just make it a module because it's never going into core".

Personally, I feel like this idea is a good candidate for a contrib, but I wouldn't fight it if it became an option in core.
